entry.title: Week 122: Beaknotes üê¶
entry.content:
• Happy New Year to all those that celebrate. On Radio 4 last week there was a woman who was asked if she was glad 2020 was over and very smugly replied that years are just arbitrary concepts and so she didn‚Äôt think one ending was important or significant. It annoyed me. I don‚Äôt disagree but can we just let the basic people who find comfort in marking the passage of time live?!. Haven‚Äôt they been through enough? Anyway. To all the time truthers out there - I see you, but save it for when we‚Äôre all feeling a bit less emotionally worn.
  • We spent the void between Christmas and New Year, 2020‚Äôs gooch if you prefer, on the edge of the Peak District with my in-laws. I spent it reading Monty Don‚Äôs new book, looking at the bird table and trying to work out if those are coal tits, blue tits or great tits (stop laughing at the back). I identified a nuthatch. It snowed the second day we were here, so Lachie and I made an igloo which our nearly-three-year-old very wisely refused to go in. We went sledding. We walked to the one place there is to walk to - a coffee shop. It‚Äôs is on a road, so definitely accessible via car, but I have no idea how that road connects to the roads here as I have only ever gotten to it over a variety of fields and bridleways. The snow made everything seem otherworldly. I saw a lot of robins sitting on snowy fenceposts, turning each still moment into a British Heart Foundation Christmas card.
  • Monty Don‚Äôs book is a lot like Gardener‚Äôs World. Slow, warm, relaxing. Short dispatches from his house near Monmouth. I‚Äôm learning a lot about birds -
    1. Robins used to be called ruddocks, and then redbreasts, and then finally robins. Redbreast is a name that predates the arrival oranges, and the concept of ‚Äúorange‚Äù. If we‚Äôd had the word ‚Äúorange‚Äù at the time we‚Äôd probably have called them ‚Äúorangebreasts‚Äù (or not, because that sounds rubbish). I guess the same goes for red squirrels and people with red hair.
    2. Moles eat worms by biting off their noses and then leaving them, alive but paralysed, in the walls of their tunnels for later.
    3. The only birdsongs I remember from growing up are those of the wood pigeon (coo coooo coo) and chaffinch, which is a tweety up-down thing that sounds like someone excitedly saying ‚Äúcheep cheep cheep cheep cheep cheep cheep cheep it‚Äôs a sneak preview!‚Äù. I‚Äôve never heard the chaffinch sound anywhere else and when I returned home this year I noticed the song was similar but had more trills than I remember. Well, thank you Monty Don for explaining that mystery to me - it‚Äôs because chaffinch songs are passed between generations, with each new generation adding its own variations, causing them to change over time.
  • Lot of bird content this week so we‚Äôre going to rebrand as‚Ä¶ Beaknotes üê¶

entry.title: Yearnotes 2020
entry.content:
OKAAAAAAAAAY well. Hm. Obviously you all know now the thing I didn‚Äôt know when I wrote my sixth year of year notes this time last year which is that a little baby coronavirus in Wuhan was about smash its was through the bodies of millions of people. Killing millions, leaving many millions more with lasting health issues, tanking economies, and just fucking shit up in an unprecedented way.

So that‚Äôs really the main thing that happened this year, which of course, you already knew.

Fambo

The big one hit 2 this year. I feel sad for the things she has missed because of the pandemic, seeing friends, playing with other children, spending time with her grandparents and cousins. She doesn‚Äôt mind at all and accepts what is happening freely. The first lockdown - March to June - was incredibly tough. She was at home because nursery closed and Lachie and I were both working full time and looking after her, which we did in shifts (7am-1pm or 1pm-7pm). I was also in my final trimester which made me more tired still. The parks were shut and so we pretty much stayed in the house and didn‚Äôt see anyone. I did a lot of crying and a lot of running the washing up water slightly too hot so the pain of feeling would be replaced by the pain of my hands burning.

In June the nursery opened back up and my maternity leave started.

And then, in July, just after the lockdown eased up, baby C was born. He‚Äôs a chucklehead, especially for his big sister. Imagine being born during a pandemic. Unlike the first birth, this one was easy and we were in and out within a few hours.

Baby C is now 6 months old. He has my dimples.

Getting to spend so much more time with my immediate family this year has been special.

More weaknotes

Despite‚Ä¶ all this‚Ä¶ I still wrote weaknotes every week, although some of them were pretty grim. In my head only a handful of people read them but then every so often someone surprising will mention they‚Äôve read them and I think ‚Äúoh christ did I say fuck or bugger or reveal anything too embarrassing recently?‚Äù.

We still vegetarian over here

Something that made being vegetarian a lot easier was working from home. Since I haven‚Äôt been into the office since March (March! Can you even believe it) I don‚Äôt have to look at a pulled pork sandwich and then choose the cheese one. It‚Äôs only cheese sandwiches.

Everybody work work work work work work

I was only at work for 6 months this year as I had a baby in July. I think the main thing that happened with work was I got onto a thing called the Next Generation Board. It‚Äôs 12 people from around the FT getting together every month or so, working on some self initiated projects, and mentoring the actual board members. I was assigned the editor, Roula Khalaf, to mentor. The project I worked on with 3 other people was defining the FT‚Äôs environmental strategy for the next 10 years and getting the board to sign off on it. By the time I left for maternity leave it was going quite well, the strategy was agreed upon and the first step (an audit by the Carbon Trust) was about to begin. It was a fascinating piece of work and I‚Äôm looking forward to getting back into it when I return to work in March. As for work in Customer Products, the biggest most memorable thing was the mid-march scramble to get everyone out of the office and working from home. I can‚Äôt remember anything that happened January - March. Presumably just doing the crossword with Edds and the gang and eating Japanese Canteen spicy tofu. That radio show was great craic too.

Did we have any time for making things?

Not a bumper year for making things, between the pandemic, the pregnancy and subsequent baby, the pre-existing child, the job, there wasn‚Äôt a lot of time for craft. The things I did make and have photos of are here

Holidays

One holiday got cancelled, but has been rescheduled for next August (welp). The other, a trip to Norfolk with my parents, happened in September. We had hire bikes, and strapped baby C‚Äôs car seat to the back of a bike buggy trailer. Then the six of us pootled along quiet country lanes to various beaches, it was heaven. Take me back to rural Norfolk where the roads are empty and the blackberries are abundant.

The garden

Last year I said I was going to try harder this year, and so that‚Äôs what I did. The tomatoes were especially good, but I also grew lots of flowers and enough strawberries to feed a toddler. Though the pandemic meant lots of things that would have happened didn‚Äôt, it did mean I formed relationships with my neighbours that would never normally have had the time to grow. My row of houses have some quite low back fences, so you can talk to your neighbours but also your neighbour‚Äôs neighbours. I had chats, almost daily, with Marlene, Trish, The Other Alice, and Dave and Dangerous Dawn during the March-June lockdown.

Thassit

And that‚Äôs that. My 7th year of Yearnotes. The rest are here if you wanted to remember the beforetimes. (2019, 2018, 2017, 2016, 2015, 2014). In 2021 I hope we‚Äôll move to Brighton but I want to do it so badly, and there are so many parts to it that are outside of my control, that I‚Äôm almost afraid to say it out loud. I‚Äôm also going to try and regain some core strength this year, which I gave away freely to have babies but now I‚Äôm done with that it‚Äôs time to take the long view of my corporeal form which I think means do some exercise.

entry.title: Week 121: Bisto
entry.content:
• Three of E‚Äôs classmates from nursery tested positive for Covid 19 this week so it‚Äôs good that we took her out of nursery early.
  • I‚Äôve found some more composure since last Sunday when I was too upset to bother with weaknotes.
  • Tomorrow we‚Äôre going to our government approved support bubble. The cynical leftwing press has speculated that the only reason families, such as ours, with a child under 1, are allowed a support bubble is because Boris Johnson has a child under one. But I‚Äôm sure our Prime Minister would never do something so blatantly self serving.
  • Christmas day at our house was nice. I made some very good vegetarian food for our lunch - the ‚ÄúKiller Roast Dinner‚Äù from Anna Jones. Lachie said it was delicious and then in the very next breath asked if we had any Bisto so he‚Äôs murdered now. (We don‚Äôt have any Bisto, of course we don‚Äôt)
  • Baby C ‚Äúate‚Äù his first solid food, a Yorkshire pudding. He was really into it.
  • I have a new stitching instagram (alices_stitch_log), primarily because I follow hastags for patterns I‚Äôm thinking of making on Instagram to see what other people are doing, but it‚Äôs made me want to contribute my own versions too. My main instagram account is private because it has lots of photos of my kids on it and only people I like get to see those üòò

entry.title: Lullaby Layette from Oliver and S

link.title: Lullaby Layette from Oliver and S

entry.content:
The other day I threw some clean clothes on my infant son and thought ‚Äúgod - he looks like he‚Äôs about to pop to B&Q and then down spoons with his mates to watch the game. He‚Äôll stumble in at 4pm scratching his balls and asking what‚Äôs for dinner before falling into a sweaty sleep on the sofa. I want my son to be a poet, or at least an accountant who has read some poetry‚Äù. Why are all affordable baby clothes so aggressively heteronormative? Anyway. That was the prompt I needed to finish this lullaby layette set which I cut a long time ago but didn‚Äôt manage to sew up.

The Onesie

The onesie is for a baby aged 3-6 months, which my baby was once. It no longer fits him because he is, as I keep telling him, such a big boy now yes he is. The fabric was from Cloth House, the body is called ‚ÄúJapanese Wind White‚Äù, and the binding is ‚ÄúJapanese Wind Navy‚Äù. Those links don‚Äôt work at the moment because the website is ‚Äúclosed for Christmas‚Äù (lol ok).

This was really fun to sew and my son looked extremely cute in it. This onesie works well in summer but looks a bit strange under trousers because it is so puffy around the tum.

The Jacket

This jacket is reversible and I am obsessed obsessed with this rabbit fabric which I used as a lining. It‚Äôs also from Cloth House. The outer fabric is some leftover Japanese seersucker printed with small crosses which I made a vest out of a while back. Using seersucker has given this jacket a crumpled quality which hopefully means I won‚Äôt have to iron it because nobody has time for that.

The Trousers

These were great. Fun to sew, very sturdy feeling with lots of room for baby to roll and wiggle around in. I made them using some corduroy from Merchant and Mills leftover from a shirt I made a while back. They appear to have sold out of it. Annoyingly I cut one of the pockets upside down so it has the wrong NAP to the other one ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. He won‚Äôt care I guess. He doesn‚Äôt even know he has hands.

I‚Äôd like to make these again but also these babies man, they really eat into the sewing time.

entry.title: Tencel florence
entry.content:
Back in March before‚Ä¶ all this‚Ä¶ I went to Rye with Nat. It was a lovely day. I was 5 months pregnant and we mostly went to the Merchant and Mills shop and tried to work out how long we could leave it between eating things.

On that trip I bought some tencel twill. It has the most lovely drape. It feels very luxurious.

I made another Florence top, but of course I was quite pregnant by the time I finished it. So here we are now, in December, I‚Äôve finally gotten around to photographing it.

entry.title: Week 119: Goofy tooth
entry.content:
• woi oi!
  • This week I was reminded of the acronym from university: BNOC (pronounced be-nock). Big Name On Campus. In case it isn‚Äôt obvious, I was not a BNOC.
  • C has a little goofy tooth and so has started biting me. It‚Äôs very unpleasant but avoidable if I really pay attention to him while feeding him.
  • We‚Äôre selling our house. We‚Äôve had 6 viewings in 3 days and it has been mad stressful keeping the place tidy and getting out of the house for the viewings. I will not be taking further questions at this time.
  • Don‚Äôt know if this is a sign of the times or a sign of early onset dementia, but I have been really enjoying ‚ÄúSpin The Wheel‚Äù, a celebrity(!) gameshow(!) on Saturday night(!) presented by Michael Mcintyre(!!!).
  • This piece about her mother dying earlier this year by Becky is extremely tender and funny and wonderfully written.
  • My 2.5 year old now comes with an 100% Lice Free Guarantee.
  • I had a Keeping In Touch day on Monday. It was really good. Normally I‚Äôd have gone in for this and seen people face to face, but because of‚Ä¶ all this I just popped up to the attic and did zoom calls. And occasionally a baby was brought to me for feeding.
  • One of the things on the KIT day was some training and on the training the instructor said: You could be sitting looking at a piece of paper with a ‚Äú9‚Äù on it, and I could be sat opposite and say ‚Äúno that‚Äôs a 6‚Äù and we‚Äôd both be right because we just have different perspectives. I was struggling to keep a straight face to the extent that I nearly had to turn my camera off. Really makes u think.

entry.title: Week 118: Gay abandon
entry.content:
• Hullo.
  • We‚Äôre going to pop in a cheeky two week isolation before Christmas so we can spend the Christmas week with my in-laws, shaking the shit out of each other‚Äôs hands, shouting in unventilated spaces until we‚Äôre hoarse and breathing in each other‚Äôs mouths with gay abandon. Just like baby Jesus would have wanted.
  • This is possible because I‚Äôm on maternity leave anyway so taking my two year old out of nursery is er‚Ä¶ easy peasy.
  • Speaking of nursery. E‚Äôs head has become the home to a single mother and about 20 children again because somebody at nursery did not delouse themselves thoroughly enough.
  • I know what you‚Äôre thinking - just use the shampoo? No my dudes - the shampoo doesn‚Äôt work on the eggs! I swear it used to? Like when we were little? Anyway - those were the good old days before smothering our children‚Äôs heads in pesticides was considered a bit reckless.
  • We went to Southend-on-sea today and it was amazing. I ate some fresh hot doughnuts. They were amazing. Hot, pillowy, sugary, perfect.
  • Back in February E came home with a card that said ‚ÄúMummy, I love you from the bottom of my heart to the tips of my toes‚Äù with a heart made by her footprints. Sweet, you think, but hang on a second - the bottom of her heart to the tips of her toes? That‚Äôs like, 2/3rds of her at best? and most of that is either bowels or legs? THINK IT THROUGH PEOPLE. I still think about it.

entry.title: Week 117: Water
entry.content:
• Stressful week. Trying to remember to drink enough water.
  • Drinking water, like brushing my teeth very throughly, it is something that calms me down because it is good for me and it doesn‚Äôt rub up against any of my ongoing low-level worries - the environment, my health and money. But also, every cell of my human-baby-son must pass through my body first. This chonky boy drinks a lot of milk so I have to produce a lot. Water is the main component of breast milk so I‚Äôve got to drink enough for two.
  • Also did you know that production of breastmilk has been shown to leech calcium from a mother‚Äôs bones, if they were not consuming enough. That‚Äôs how serious my body is taking feeding this baby.
  • Did you know there is a reddit for people who love drinking water. It‚Äôs just relatable memes of TFW you wake up in the middle of the night very thirsty and then have a nice glass of water. Hydro homies

entry.title: Week 116: Lefty
entry.content:
• It is a small source of pride that I have a left-handed child. All the left-handed people I can think of are geniuses, so I think the writing is on the wall (albeit a bit smudged).
  • Really pleased with that joke, could just stop there to be honest.
  • More often than not lefty sleeps with a pair of trousers on her head. She also sleeps on the floor not in her bed. That‚Äôs some genius isht right there, no?
  • Weeks of picking up mouse poo every damn morning, this week we murdered our first mouse.
  • I attended some work meetings this week. I logged in to my work email because I needed to ask for my P60, and then one thing led to another‚Ä¶ At the time I justified it by saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to take a KIT day in a few weeks, so I should be up to speed on some stuff before then‚Äù. But of course what was really happening was I was interested and lacked the self discipline to keep a boundary between maternity leave time and work. The problem with doing this is it creates the illusion of me being available when in reality I‚Äôm not. Anyway I have now signed back out of gmail and will not be signing back in.
  • So back to singing Moon River to baby C while he goes HAM in his bouncer.
  • In one of the work meetings I attended someone was smoking a cigarette on the call. Is‚Ä¶ that‚Ä¶ OK? You‚Äôre in your own home so it‚Äôs not a problem for others. And yet they were clearly trying to hide it‚Ä¶ and it did feel to me very much like the actions of someone who had zero shits left to give. Basically - the question for Ask A Manager is ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôre all working from home, is it unprofessional to smoke during meetings‚Äù
  • I made some Christmas decorations with E a few weeks ago, this week I jiffy bagged them and set off to post them to four friends and relatives. On the way to the post box I put some clothes in the clothes bank. When I arrived at the post box two of the sets of decorations were missing. I don‚Äôt even know which two because I posted the two that were there before realising I had lost half the cargo. I retraced my steps but didn‚Äôt find anything. So - maybe someone found them and posted them, maybe someone found them and threw them in the bin, maybe I put them in the clothes bank. I‚Äôll keep you all updated. [Update: Both sets of grandparents have received their decorations]
  • Last week I was so anxious that I wrote (but then deleted because it was too boring): ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt tell if everything is awful or I‚Äôm just about to get my period back‚Äù. Anyway this week, much to my surprise I did indeed have a very small period. The first in about a year. Pretty satisfied that I managed to identify the source of that tightness in the chest despite it being so long.
